This question is only intended to capture those individuals who have been formally appointed as a mediator and recognized by both workers and management.

questions.label: What percentage of all full-time employees have been granted stock, stock options, or stock equivalents (including participation in an ESOP or other qualified ownership plans) in the company?
questions.guidance: Select N/A if your company is a consumer/shared services cooperative, a producer cooperative or a nonprofit.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of company owners, the ownership type held, and whether the individual is a full-time employee of the company. 

More Details
Spreadsheet or modified capitalization table should include:

1) Owner’s name or identifier (e.g. Owner 1, 2, etc).
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time).
3) Employee title.
4) Type of ownership held (i.e. stock, stock options, stock equivalents).
5) Total number of full-time employees at the company.

Reminders
You may redact owner names on any document.

The scope of this question includes all full-time employees of the company, e.g. founders, executives, non-executive employees, etc.

questions.summary: % of Company Owned by Non-Management Employees
questions.label: What percentage of your company is owned by non-executive, non-management level workers through an ownership vehicle paid for by the company that does not require employee contributions?
questions.guidance: Select N/A if your company is a consumer/shared services cooperative, a producer cooperative or a nonprofit.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate 1) how employees obtain ownership in the company and 2) a list of non-executive and non-manager company owners, the amount of shares owned by each, and the sum of all company shares.

More Details
Documents that show evidence of the mechanism by which employees become owners could be the relevant section of the employee handbook, the benefits packet for an entry-level employee, etc. The spreadsheet or modified capitalization table should include:

1) Owner’s name or identifier (e.g. Owner 1, 2, etc).
2) Employee title.
3) Type of ownership held (i.e. stock, stock options, stock equivalents).
4) Amount of shares owned by each employee that did not require their financial contribution.
5) Total company shares.

Reminders
You may redact owner names on any document.

questions.label: What are your company practices regarding equipment or machinery used by workers?
questions.guidance: This includes machinery, vehicles, etc. Check all that apply. Select N/A only if the company has no equipment.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company ensures the safe operation of machinery. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Dated training materials (e.g. slide deck, video, handouts, etc) and/or a calendar that includes scheduled trainings on the proper operation and dangers of equipment or machinery.
Checkbox 2: Pictures and descriptions of protective gear or a list of items workers are required to wear.
Checkbox 3: Dated inspection checklist.
Checkbox 4: Dated maintenance report.
Checkbox 5: Picture of materials describing the hazards and proper use of equipment posted on or near machinery.
Checkbox 6: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding the safe operation of equipment or machinery.

questions.summary: Surveying and Benchmarking Engagement and Attrition
questions.label: Does your company monitor and evaluate your worker satisfaction and engagement in any of the following ways?
questions.guidance: Your answers determine which future questions in the assessment are applicable to your company.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how the company tracks employee attrition and engagement. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Employee attrition report.
Checkbox 2 & 6: Employee attrition report that includes industry benchmarks.
Checkbox 3: Dated employee satisfaction surveys for the past two years.
Checkbox 4 & 7: Summary report of employee satisfaction data that includes industry benchmarks.
Checkbox 5: Attrition and/or satisfaction reports that breaks down data by different demographic groups.

questions.label: Have your company's labor practices been certified or reviewed by an independent third party in the last twelve months?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a dated independent review report or certification of the company’s labor practices. If applicable, please also include the criteria that must be met to earn the certificate.

questions.label: What are your company policies around hazardous or dangerous materials on-site?
questions.guidance: Hazardous materials include chemicals, gasoline or fuel, fertilizer, pesticides, etc.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company ensures the safe handling of hazardous or dangerous materials. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Dated training materials (e.g. slide deck, video, handouts, etc) and/or a calendar that includes scheduled trainings on the proper storage, handling, and disposal of hazardous materials.
Checkbox 2: Pictures and descriptions of protective gear or a list of items workers are required to wear.
Checkbox 3: Materials describing all of the health risks associated with handling hazardous materials (e.g. policies, flyers, handbooks, or training resources).
Checkbox 4: Health/safety policy or relevant section of employee handbook that states what steps the company is taking to monitor the health of those who work with hazardous materials, including an annual check-up. 
Checkbox 5: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding company policies on the management of on-site hazardous or dangerous materials handled by workers.

questions.label: What is covered in your company's written non-discrimination policy on hiring and the workplace?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide your company’s non-discrimination policy or the relevant section of your employee handbook.

Reminders
To qualify for this question, your company must have a written non-discrimination policy that covers both hiring and the work environment. Codifying a company’s expectations in writing helps to ensure that your values are consistently practiced within the company.

questions.label: What are your company's occupational health and safety policies?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company protects its employees from on-the-job accidents and injury. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Occupational health/safety policies and pictures of mechanisms in place to minimize accidents (please also include captions for any photographs).
Checkbox 2: Picture of bulletin board with injury, accident, lost or absentee day data or an email containing this information sent to all employees.
Checkbox 3: Minutes from a Health and Safety Committee meeting. Please also provide a list of members and their title at the company.

questions.label: What percentage of employees has received specialized training on policies and procedures concerning aspects of labor or human rights that are relevant to the company's operations?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of employees that have had specific training on labor or human rights relevant to the company’s operations.

More Details
Spreadsheet or modified employee roster should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (Title or Employee 1, 2, etc).
2) Description of the training/s that each received.
3) Total number of employees.

questions.label: What is required in your company's formal safety and health program?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate what mechanisms are in place to protect the health and safety of your employees at work. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Dated safety training (e.g. slide deck, video, handouts, etc) and evidence of an emergency drill (e.g. results analysis, email announcement, etc).
Checkbox 2: Picture of bulletin board with injury, accident, lost or absentee day data or an email containing this information sent to all employees.
Checkbox 3: Excerpt from employee handbook that states how employees can report their safety concerns.
Checkbox 4: Job description for safety position/program representative or committee charter that includes who those individuals are expected to report to.
Checkbox 5: Policy for accident/incident investigation.
Checkbox 6: Incident response report that includes corrective actions taken.
Checkbox 7: Results from the most recent annual evaluation of the company’s safety/health system.

Reminders
Practices selected should be a part of consistent and structured program to provide a safe work environment, not occasional activities.

questions.label: How have your company's labor practices been certified or reviewed by an independent third party in the last twelve months?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate to what degree your company has monitored its labor practices and/or how it has shared the results in the last twelve months. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 2: Dated independent certification or review report of the company’s labor practices. Please also include evidence that clearly indicates that the scope of the certification/review reflects 50%+ of the company’s operations.
Checkbox 3: Link to government webpage with the required performance standard for human rights as well as the criteria for a review/certificate that your company has completed in the past 12 months and the review report/certificate (if not already uploaded).
Checkbox 4: Dated stakeholder communications (e.g. emails, slide decks, mailings, etc) or a link to webpage that includes compliance report data.

questions.label: What is included in your company's written and accessible employee handbook?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please upload your company’s employee handbook and indicate on which page each selected answer option can be found.

questions.label: Have your company's labor practices been certified or reviewed by an independent third party during the last 12 months?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate to what degree your company has monitored its labor practices and/or how it has shared the results in the last twelve months. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 2: Dated independent certification or review report of the company’s labor practices. Please also include evidence that clearly indicates that the scope of the certification/review reflects 50%+ of the company’s operations.
Checkbox 3: Link to government webpage with the required performance standard for human rights as well as the criteria for a review/certificate that your company has completed in the past 12 months and the review report/certificate (if not already uploaded).
Checkbox 4: Dated stakeholder communications (e.g. emails, slide decks, mailings, etc) or a link to webpage that includes compliance report data.

questions.label: How does your company manage the scheduling process for hourly workers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate what consistent and responsive scheduling systems the company has created to benefit hourly workers. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Distributed policy, relevant section of employee handbook, offer letter for an hourly worker, etc. that sets minimum work hours.
Checkbox 2: Distributed policy, relevant section of employee handbook, etc. which states that worker preference must be incorporated into scheduling.
Checkbox 3: Dated communications to employees that includes their schedules.
Checkbox 4: Distributed policy, relevant section of employee handbook, offer letter for an hourly worker, etc. which states that worker schedules will be consistent from week to week or at least three hourly employee schedules from the past three months.  
Checkbox 5: Distributed policy, relevant section of employee handbook, offer letter for an hourly worker, etc. that describes how to exchange hours, screengrab of a technology platform available to employees that facilitates this practice.
Checkbox 6: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding how your company manages the scheduling process for hourly workers.

questions.label: Does the company offer any of the following job flexibility options, whenever feasible, in writing and in practice for the majority of workers?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the flexible career options available to the majority of employees. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents may include the relevant section of the employee handbook, a benefits packet, new employee orientation materials, etc. 

Please also upload the number of employees currently taking advantage of each job flexibility opportunity selected.

Reminders
To qualify for this question, employees must have access to a written description of the job flexibility options your company offers. If your company engages in these benefits in practice but not in writing, you will receive credit elsewhere.

questions.summary: Management Commitment to Health and Safety
questions.label: What are your company practices regarding management's commitment to worker health and safety?
questions.guidance: Select those that apply to all company worksites.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the actions that your company’s management takes to create a safe and healthy worksite for employees. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Health and Safety Policy.
Checkbox 2: Minutes from a senior management planning meeting that includes 1) a discussion on employee safety and health and 2) participation by worker representatives. 
Checkbox 3: Dated health and safety training materials (e.g. slide decks, handouts, videos, etc), calendar of training.
Checkbox 4: Report that includes specific health and safety program goals, objectives, and indicators of progress.
Checkbox 5: Email communications or meeting agendas that show senior management addressing safety issues at least quarterly.
Checkbox 6: Photograph or screengrab of a safety reporting system available to workers, relevant section of employee handbook. 
Checkbox 7: Photographs of posted safety procedures around relevant sites.
Checkbox 8: External program certificate (please also include the criteria necessary to achieve certification).

questions.label: Your company's practices related to inspections and audits include:
questions.guidance: Select those that apply to all company worksites.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate your company’s inspections and audit procedures. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Health and safety inspections policies, checklists, etc.
Checkbox 2: Inspections schedule, quarterly inspection results.
Checkbox 3: Email announcement, flyer posted, etc. regarding an improvement of safety procedures made as a result of information collected.
Checkbox 4: Most recent routine inspection results report.
Checkbox 5: Most recent routine inspection results report that includes a required correction and an assignment of accountability.

questions.label: What supplementary benefits are provided to a majority of non-managerial workers?
questions.guidance: Including full time and part time employees. Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation on the benefits your company provides to the majority of its non-managerial employees, above and beyond what is required by law. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents include an employee handbook, receipts of payment for services provided, and/or pictures of onsite services provided with detailed captions.

Reminders
Items selected must be available to at least 80% of non-managerial employees. In general terms, non-managerial employees are responsible for their own workload but not the overall direction of the company or the management of other individuals. 

Any affirmative answer should reflect a benefit that your company chose to offer its employees and their families, not a legal obligation.

questions.label: What is included in your company's measurement and evaluation practices in relation to occupational safety and health?
questions.guidance: Select those that apply to all company worksites.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company monitors and improves its occupational health and safety programs. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Third-party safety management system.
Checkbox 2: Job description for your company’s safety position/program representative or a Safety Committee’s governing documents. Either should includes responsibilities and who the individual/group reports to.
Checkbox 3: Accidents and major incidents investigation procedures.  
Checkbox 4: Example of a root cause investigation as a result of an accident or incident.
Checkbox 5: Corrective action procedures.
Checkbox 6: Posted flyer, email communication to all workers, etc. that includes injury or illness data.
Checkbox 7: Most recent annual evaluation of the company’s occupational health and safety systems. Please indicate the page/s in which senior management is evaluated.
Checkbox 8: Section of employee handbook that describes the worker safety recognition program, posted criteria for participation in the employee safety recognition program.
Checkbox 9: Results from the two most recent Safety Perception surveys.

questions.label: What supplementary benefits are provided to a majority of non-managerial workers?
questions.guidance: Including full time and part time employees. Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation on the benefits your company provides to the majority of its non-managerial employees, above and beyond what is required by law. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents include an employee handbook, receipts of payment for services provided, and/or pictures of onsite services provided with detailed captions.

Reminders
Items selected must be available to at least 80% of non-managerial employees. In general terms, non-managerial employees are responsible for their own workload but not the overall direction of the company or the management of other individuals. 

Any affirmative answer should reflect a benefit that your company chose to offer its employees and their families, not a legal obligation.

questions.label: What job flexibility options does the company provide, whenever feasible, in writing and in practice for the majority of workers?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the flexible career options available to the majority of employees. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents may include the relevant section of the employee handbook, a benefits packet, new employee orientation materials, etc. 

Please also upload the number of employees currently taking advantage of each job flexibility opportunity selected.

Reminders
To qualify for this question, employees must have access to a written description of the job flexibility options your company offers. If your company engages in these benefits in practice but not in writing, you will receive credit elsewhere.

questions.label: What are your company's policies and practices around career development and promotion?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation that shows what options are available to employees returning from sabbaticals as well as the possibility of lateral or horizontal mobility within the company. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents include sabbatical and/or career development policies, the relevant section of the employee handbook, or an offer letter for an entry-level employee that refers to the selected practice/s.

Alternatively, please upload a list of employees that have taken advantage of a selected policy/practice in the past 24 months. The list should denote the particular benefit utilized by each employee.

Reminders
You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: Which of the following flexible workplace practices have been used in the past 12 months?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the flexible career options utilized by employees in the past 12 months. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1-2: Modified employee roster or spreadsheet that lists the managers or executives with flexible schedules in the past 12 months. Document must include the worker’s title and whether the individual consistently works a part-time, job-share, or telecommuting position.
Checkbox 3-4: Modified employee roster or spreadsheet that lists new hires with flexible schedules in the past 12 months. Document must include the worker’s employment status (permanent or temporary) and whether the individual was hired to work a part-time, job-share, or telecommuting position.
Checkbox 5: Modified employee roster or spreadsheet that lists the employees who have transitioned into a part-time, job-share, or telecommuting position in the past 12 months. 
Checkbox 6: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding flexible workplace practices used by workers at the company in the past 12 months.

Reminders
You may redact employee names on any document provided (i.e. use Employee 1, 2, etc instead).

questions.label: Is the majority (over 50%) of the company's ownership located locally to at least two-thirds of the company's workforce?
questions.guidance: “Local" is defined as being part of the same community. While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, they should generally be based on a small-scale economically and culturally connected area like a metropolitan area or a city/town.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) a list of company owners that includes the number of shares held and their place of residence and 2) the number of workers employed at each company facility.

More Details
List of owners or modified capitalization table should include:

1) Owner’s name or identifier (e.g. Owner 1, 2, etc).
2) Number of shares owned by that individual.
3) City, state, and country where the owner spends the majority of their time
4) Total number of company shares of all types.

Please also list the address of each company facility and the number of payrolled employees at each location.

Reminders
You may redact owner names on any document provided.

questions.label: We realize that for companies with more than one office, the definition of local involvement is a more complicated one to answer. Please tell us a bit about the structure of your company geographically.
What was the percentage of per capita worker time donated as volunteer, community service, or pro bono time in the reporting period?
questions.guidance: Calculate by total volunteer hours / total hours worked, generally 2000 hours per FTE.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a spreadsheet that shows how much time each employee spends on volunteer/community service/pro-bono work and how many hours the employee works overall.

More Details
Spreadsheet or modified employee roster should include:

1) List of all company employees.
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time, part-time).
3) Total hours worked by each employee in either the last fiscal year or the last 12 months.
4) Total volunteer/community service/pro-bono hours donated by each employee in the last fiscal year or the last 12 months.

Reminders
If your company has full-time salaried employees and does not keep track of individual hours worked, please use 2,080 hours as an approximate value (i.e. 40 hours a week for 52 weeks).

questions.label: What percentage of your company's expenses (excluding labor) was spent with independent suppliers local to the company's headquarters or relevant facilities in the last fiscal year?
questions.guidance: Please click "Learn More" to understand how to answer this question.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of suppliers that are independently-owned and local to your company's operations, the amount spent with each, and a list of your company's facilities.   

More Details
Supplier list or spreadsheet should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Total cost of goods/services purchased from that supplier in the last fiscal year.
3) Supplier’s address.
4) Link to the supplier’s website.
5) Total amount spent with all suppliers last fiscal year. 

Please also list the address of each company facility and the number of payrolled employees at each location.

Reminders
A supplier is any business that your company pays to provide a good or service. However, in the B Impact Assessment, suppliers will always exclude 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Other questions in the assessment speak to these providers. 

To qualify for this question, a supplier cannot be a majority-owned subsidiary of another company or a publicly-traded company. It must be independently-owned.

While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, local should generally be defined as a small-scale economically and culturally connected area. Examples include a metropolitan area or, in a less densely populated area, a county or the surrounding vicinity (usually within 50 miles or less).

questions.label: What percentage of your company's Cost of Goods Sold (including value-adding activities) was spent within the country of operations, from in-country registered companies or national citizens?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please list the suppliers that are based in your country of operations who made up your Cost of Goods Sold in the last fiscal year and the amount spent with each.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Total Cost of Goods/Services purchased from that supplier during the last fiscal year.
3) Country of the supplier’s headquarters or main office.
4) Total Cost of Goods Sold in the last fiscal year.

Reminders
Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) are direct costs required to produce a company’s product or service.

questions.label: What percentage of employees took paid time off for volunteer service last year?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of all employees and indicate those who took paid or unpaid time off for community service in the last fiscal year.

questions.label: Does your company provide your procurement staff or departments with any of the following?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company encourages your procurement team to purchase from local suppliers.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Policy that states what factors that can be considered beyond a competitive bid when selecting a supplier.
Checkbox 2: RFP posting protocol/checklist.
Checkbox 3: Training or materials given to employees on how to source from local or independent suppliers (e.g. slide decks, handouts, videos, etc).
Checkbox 4: List of incentives that encourage sourcing from local suppliers.  

Reminders
While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, local should generally be defined as a small-scale economically and culturally connected area. Examples include a metropolitan area or, in a less densely populated area, a county or the surrounding vicinity (usually within 50 miles/80 km or less). 

To be independent, a supplier cannot be a majority-owned subsidiary of another company or a publicly traded company.

questions.label: Executives
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of all executives that includes 1) their title, 2) the location at which they work and 3) an explanation of what makes that person a native of that area (i.e. born in the same city, state, etc).

Reminders
An executive is someone who is employed by a business at the highest level. Executives decide what the business should do and ensures that it is done. Their scope of work usually extends beyond the management of individual person or project.

questions.label: What was the equivalent percentage of revenue donated to charity during the last fiscal year?
questions.guidance: Please include tax deductible in-kind donations but do not include pro bono time.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of tax-deductible donations made to registered charities in the last fiscal year and your company revenues during that time period. 

More Details
Spreadsheet should include:

1) Charity name.
2) Charity website or, if not available, a link to a government charity register that includes the recipient charity.
3) Total amount donated to that charity in the last fiscal year.
4) Total company revenues in the last fiscal year.

Reminders
The focus of this question is cash donations. Pro-bono time should not be included. 

Please only list donations for which your company can show receipts.

questions.label: We realize for large companies that have numerous facilities and multinational operations, the definition of local is potentially complex. Please briefly describe the structure of your company geographically, including the location and number of employees located at your headquarters and largest facilities. Also state the total number of facilities managed by your company.
Is the majority (over 50%) of the company's ownership located locally to the majority of the company's workforce?
questions.guidance: “Local" is defined as being part of the same community. While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, they should generally be based on a small-scale economically and culturally connected area like a metropolitan area or a city/town.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) a list of company owners that includes the number of shares held and their place of residence and 2) the number of workers employed at each company facility.

More Details
List of owners or modified capitalization table should include:

1) Owner’s name or identifier (e.g. Owner 1, 2, etc).
2) Number of shares owned by that individual.
3) City, state, and country where the owner spends the majority of their time
4) Total number of company shares of all types.

Please also list the address of each company facility and the number of payrolled employees at each location.

Reminders
You may redact owner names on any document provided.

questions.label: Does your company have membership or a civic partnership with any of the following types of organizations?
questions.guidance: Check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the organization/s to which your company has affliated itself. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Documents may include a partnership agreement, membership certificate, or a dues payment.

questions.label: Do a majority of your customers live locally to your company's headquarters or production facilities?
questions.guidance: “Local" is defined as being part of the same community. While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, they should generally be based on a small-scale economically and culturally connected area like a metropolitan area or a city/town.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how many of your company's customers in the last fiscal year were local to your company's operations.

More Details
Two sets of data are required 1) customer information and 2) a list of company facilities.

Customer spreadsheet (or similar) should include:
1) List of company products.
2) Revenue received from each product.
3) What percentage of that product (by revenue) was delivered or purchased by someone local to your company (i.e. calculated based on addresses on customer invoices).
4) Total revenue from all products. 

If your company is a service provider, please provide the same information but, instead of listing company products, break down your revenues by client and include the client’s address. 

Please also include the address of each company facility and the number of payrolled employees at each location.

Reminders
While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, local should generally be defined as a small-scale economically and culturally connected area. Examples include a metropolitan area or, in a less densely populated area, a county or the surrounding vicinity (usually within 50 miles or less).

questions.label: What written local purchasing or hiring policies does your company have in place?
questions.guidance: “Local" is defined as being part of the same community. While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, they should generally be based on a small-scale economically and culturally connected area like a metropolitan area or a city/town.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation that verifies your company's efforts to support its local economy through hiring and purchasing. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Local purchasing policy.
Checkbox 2: Sustainability report or annual goals that set targets for local purchasing.
Checkbox 3: List of preferred local suppliers/vendors used by purchasers.
Checkbox 4: Job posting that includes an explicit statement that local candidates are encouraged to apply for management positions or an internal HR document that states a preference for hiring managers who live near a company facility. Please also provide the starting salary for a local manager, as compared to a non-local manager. 
Checkbox 5: Job posting that includes an explicit statement that local candidates are encouraged to apply for any position or an internal HR document that states a preference for hiring individuals who live near a company facility. If not included in either of the previous documents, please also provide an employment contract for a local candidate that describes the training program available to local staff.
Checkbox 6: A staff member’s benefits package or employee handbook, which includes the incentives provided to employees who lives within 40 km of the company’s facility (e.g. transit benefits, etc).
Checkbox 7: Please provide evidence of your claim regarding your company's written local purchasing or hiring policies.

Reminders
Simply engaging in one of the behaviors mentioned above does not count for this question. There must be a written component. Codifying a company’s expectations in writing help ensure that your values regarding local purchasing and hiring are consistently practiced within the company.

If your company has more than one location, documentation must demonstrate that each facility has the identified policy for purchasing or hiring locally. 

While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, local should generally be defined as a small-scale economically and culturally connected area. Examples include a metropolitan area or, in a less densely populated area, a county or the surrounding vicinity (usually within 50 miles or less).

questions.label: Does your company provide technical assistance training or access to other community farmers that you do not source from on a pro-bono or subsidized basis?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate what pro-bono or subsidized resources your company has made available to community farmers who are not a part of your supply chain.

More Details
Sample documents include training materials, flyers from events, a link to a website describing program offerings, etc. Uploaded information must include 1) a description of the content, 2) who has access to information and 3) that the cost is either pro-bono or subsidized.

If selected, please also upload the data that shows that there has been a quantifiable increase in the productivity of those farmers (e.g. survey results, feedback forms, etc).

questions.label: What percentage of senior management is native to the country of operations?
questions.guidance: Native individuals are born and/or raised in the country.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of all senior managers, the location at which they work, and indicate whether they are a native of that country.

Reminders
An senior manager is someone who is employed by a business at a high level. Senior managers typically have a say in what the business should do and help ensure that it is done. Their scope of work usually extends beyond the management of individual person or project.

questions.summary: Policy Advocacy for Social and Environmental Standards
questions.label: Has your company worked with policymakers to develop or advocate for policy changes explicitly designed to improve social or environmental outcomes in the past two years?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation that verifies your company's intentional and official efforts to advocate for the advancement of social and environmental laws or reputable third-party standards or policies. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Letters or petitions signed by the company that state the desired outcome.
Checkbox 2: Record of financial support for (e.g. receipts or letters) or staff participation in a policymaking effort (e.g. press release, membership confirmation, event attendee list)
Checkbox 3: Written proposals, recomendations, or transcribed testimonies by the company to advance a policy or third-party standards.
Checkbox 4: Laws/third-party standards/policies that were changed or implemented due to actions made by the company and evidence of the company's involvement.
Checkbox 5: Please provide evidence of other work with policymakers to develop or advocate for policy changes explicitly designed to improve social or environmental outcomes in the past two years.

Reminders
This question captures strategic efforts to make specific advances to laws, standards or policies. General charitable or volunteer efforts will not earn credit in this question.

Please also note that activities from more than two years ago do not qualify for this question.

questions.label: How does your company take part in civic engagement?
questions.guidance: Your answers determine which future questions in the assessment are applicable to your company.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to demonstrate how the company donates its time and resources to help others. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected. 

More Details
Sample Documents:

Checkbox 1: Record of financial or in-kind donations with value of donations and the recipient charity (e.g. receipts, thank you letters, tax filings).
Checkbox 2: Stock certificates for any community investments.
Checkbox 3: Spreadsheets that track employee volunteer or pro-bono hours donated, screengrabs of volunteer management system, corporate social responsibility reports, pictures of company volunteer days.
Checkbox 4: Records of company participation in advocacy efforts to advance a specific social or environmental government policy or third-party standard (e.g. letters, petitions, hearing briefings, receipts of financial support)
Checkbox 5: Record of partnership between the business and a charitable organization (e.g. partnership agreements, website links, social impact report, governing documents) or confirmation letter of the company's membership in a community organization.
Checkbox 6: Flyers or blog posts highlighting free community events hosted at the company's facilities. 
Checkbox 7: Capitalization table (or similiar) demonstrating the total shares of the company and the number of shares owned by a nonprofit organization. 
Checkbox 8: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding how your company takes part in civic engagement. 

Reminders
Pro-bono and volunteer service is captured in Checkbox 3 and should not be monetized and counted as a charitable donation. Additionally, credit is not captured in this question for discounts given to charitable or community organizations.

questions.label: Managers
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of all managers that includes 1) their title, 2) the location at which they work and 3) an explanation of what makes that person a native of that area (i.e. born the same city, state, etc).

Reminders
Managers can include individuals who manage people or significant projects.

questions.label: How does your company manage employee community service?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation that verifies your company's intentional and official efforts to promote community engagement and volunteerism. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Record of company service days (e.g. pictures, flyers, reports).
Checkbox 2-3: Section of the employee handbook with a policy granting paid time off to employees for volunteering. 
Checkbox 4: Spreadsheet or volunteer management system screengrab that shows employee volunteer hours. 
Checkbox 5: Strategic plan or annual report that states goals for employee community service or pro-bono work. 
Checkback 6: Please provide evidence of other ways that your company manages employee community service.

questions.label: Non-managerial full-time workers
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of all non-managerial employees that includes 1) their title, 2) the location at which they work and 3) an explanation of what makes that person a native of that area (i.e. born the same city, state, etc).

Reminders
In general terms, non-managerial employees are any employee is is not a manager or an executive. These individuals are typically responsible for their own workload but not the overall direction of the company or the management of other individuals.

questions.label: What was the equivalent percentage of revenue donated to charity during the last fiscal year?
questions.guidance: Please include tax deductible in-kind donations but do not include pro bono time.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of tax-deductible donations made to registered charities in the last fiscal year and your company revenues during that time period. 

More Details
Spreadsheet should include:

1) Charity name.
2) Charity website or, if not available, a link to a government charity register that includes the recipient charity.
3) Total amount donated to that charity in the last fiscal year.
4) Total company revenues in the last fiscal year.

Reminders
The focus of this question is cash donations. Pro-bono time should not be included. 

Please only list donations for which your company can show receipts.

questions.summary: Total Amount of Volunteer Service Hours
questions.label: Number of hours volunteered by full-time and part-time employees of the organization during the last fiscal year
questions.guidance: This should include both paid and unpaid time spent volunteering during traditional work hours, either for company-organized events or for employee-initiated activities.

questions.label: What percentage of your company's Cost of Goods Sold (including value-adding activities) was spent within the country of operations, from in-country registered companies or national citizens?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please list the suppliers that are based in your country of operations who made up your Cost of Goods Sold in the last fiscal year and the amount spent with each.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Total Cost of Goods/Services purchased from that supplier during the last fiscal year.
3) Country of the supplier’s headquarters or main office.
4) Total Cost of Goods Sold in the last fiscal year.

Reminders
Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) are direct costs required to produce a company’s product or service.

questions.label: Total amount (in currency terms) donated to registered charities in the last fiscal year
questions.guidance: Report with the currency specified in "Reporting currency" for this metric.

questions.label: Number of full-time and part-time workers that departed or left the company in the last twelve months
questions.guidance: Enter 0 if None.

questions.label: What percentage of your workforce is low-income or does not have a college degree AND is also employed in company facilities located in low-income communities?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of employees who 1) meet the criteria of low-income or do not have a college degree and 2) work at a company facility located in a low-income area. Additionally, please provide the resources referenced to determine if an individual or area qualifies as low-income.

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc).
2) Address of employment.
3) Whether the employee has a college degree.
4) Whether the employee can be considered low-income and, if so, by what definition (e.g. lives in a low-income area, receive government benefits only available to low-income individuals, etc).
5) Total number of individuals currently working for the company.

Please also include a link to the data used to determine the income level an area or upload a relevant analysis.

Reminders
Companies with employees in the United States should use the following FFIEC resource to determine if an area is low-income: https://geomap.ffiec.gov/FFIECGeocMap/GeocodeMap1.aspx 

Companies with employees in other countries should use census data or other research-based evidence to verify that the low-income area is a place where the median family income is less than 80% of the median family income of the surrounding vicinity. 

You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: What was the percentage of per capita worker time donated as volunteer, community service, or pro bono time in the reporting period?
questions.guidance: Calculate by total volunteer hours / total hours worked, generally 2000 hours per FTE.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a spreadsheet that shows how much time each employee spends on volunteer/community service/pro-bono work and how many hours the employee works overall.

More Details
Spreadsheet or modified employee roster should include:

1) List of all company employees.
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time, part-time).
3) Total hours worked by each employee in either the last fiscal year or the last 12 months.
4) Total volunteer/community service/pro-bono hours donated by each employee in the last fiscal year or the last 12 months.

Reminders
If your company has full-time salaried employees and does not keep track of individual hours worked, please use 2,080 hours as an approximate value (i.e. 40 hours a week for 52 weeks).

questions.label: What percentage of full-time and part-time hourly workers left the company during the last twelve months?
questions.guidance: Calculation should include voluntary and involuntary separation, but exclude workers dismissed with cause.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide two lists: 1) a list of all current hourly employees and 2) a list of all hourly employees who worked for the company 12 months ago, noting the type of dismissal for employees who are no longer with the company.

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (i.e. Employee 1, Employee 2, etc). 
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time, part-time).
3) Wage type (i.e. hourly).
4) Type of dismissal, if applicable (i.e. voluntary separation, involuntary separation (without cause), dismissed with cause, etc).

Reminders
Termination with cause requires provable misconduct or documented performance problems with the employee.

questions.label: What was your company’s net job growth rate for full-time and part-time positions over the last 12 months? ONLY include newly created jobs that are paid a living wage.
questions.guidance: If there is no living wage data available for your country of operations, include new jobs that pay 10% or more above a minimum wage.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of current full and part-time workers and a list of full and part-time workers from 12 months ago that includes the wages of any employees hired to fill a new position (i.e. not an individual hired to replace someone).

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include the following:

1) Employee name or other indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc) for all employees as of the present day and 12 months ago.
2) Title.
3) Employment status and, if part-time, how many hours worked per week.

For the employees who were hired for a new position in the past 12 months, please also provide:

1) Employee's hourly pay (If the living wage date used is broken down by month vs. by hour, please calculate your employee's monthly salary instead (i.e. match your employee wage information to the pay period of the living wage data)).
2) Address of employment.
3) Living wage data for your area, including a link to the referenced source.

Reminders
The living wage is not the minimum wage. A living wage goes beyond meeting the minimum wage required by law and ensures that employees have the money necessary to meet living expenses in your region. It is a market-based approach that draws upon geographically specific expenditure data related to an individual’s likely minimum food, health insurance, housing, transportation, and other basic necessities (e.g. clothing, personal care items, etc.) costs.

Accepted living wage data can be found at the links below:

Canada: http://livingwagecanada.ca/
United Kingdom: livingwage.org.uk/calculation
United States: livingwage.mit.edu
Selected other countries: https://www.globallivingwage.org/

You may redact employee names on any document.

questions.label: What written local purchasing or hiring policies does your company have in place?
questions.guidance: “Local" is defined as being part of the same community. While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, they should generally be based on a small-scale economically and culturally connected area like a metropolitan area or a city/town.

More Details

Checkbox 3: List of preferred local suppliers/vendors used by purchasers.
Checkbox 4: Job posting that includes an explicit statement that local candidates are encouraged to apply for management positions or an internal HR document that states a preference for hiring managers who live near a company facility. 
Checkbox 5: A staff member’s benefits package or employee handbook, which includes the incentives provided to employees who lives within 20 miles of the company’s facility (e.g. transit benefits, etc).

While the size and distance of a community may vary by context, local should generally be defined as a small-scale economically and culturally connected area. Examples include a metropolitan area or, in a less densely populated area, a county or the surrounding vicinity (usually within 50 miles or less).

questions.label: What percentage of your workforce lives in poor/very poor or low-income areas or does not have college degree?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of current workers (of any employment type) that shows how many of those individuals live in a low-income area or do not have a college degree. Additionally, please provide the resource that was referenced to determine if an area is low-income.

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc).
2) Employment status (full-time, part-time, contractor, etc).
2) Whether the employee has a college degree.
3) Whether the employee lives in a low-income area and, if so, the employee's address.
4) Total number of individuals currently working for the company (of any employment type).

Please also include a link to the data used to determine the income level of the addresses or upload the relevant demographic analysis.

Reminders
Companies with employees in the United States should use the following FFIEC resource to determine if an area is low-income: https://geomap.ffiec.gov/FFIECGeocMap/GeocodeMap1.aspx. 

Companies with employees in other countries should use census data or other research-based evidence. 

You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: What characteristics apply to the financial institution that provides the majority of your company's banking services?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a recent statement from the bank that handles the majority of your company’s financial needs and a link to the bank’s website.

More Details
If your company has more than one bank, please upload documentation regarding your primary bank relationship, defined by bank deposit size and assets held. The statement should clearly indicates the name of both the bank and your company. 

Reminders
The balance amount and other sensitive information can be redacted on the statement.

questions.label: What percentage of your Significant Suppliers is located in low-income communities or create employment opportunities for other chronically underemployed populations?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) a list of your significant suppliers from the last fiscal year who are either located in low-income communities or who seek to employ chronically underemployed populations and 2) the amount spent with each last fiscal year. 

More Details
Spreadsheet should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Supplier website.
3) Supplier address.
4) Description of how the supplier meets the criteria of the question (e.g. results of analysis completed using supplier address and/or supplier’s mission statement).
5) Amount spent with each supplier last fiscal year.
6) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers last fiscal year.

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses. 

Companies with employees in the United States should use the following FFIEC resource to determine if an area is low-income: https://geomap.ffiec.gov/FFIECGeocMap/GeocodeMap1.aspx 

Companies with employees in other countries should use census data or other research-based evidence to verify that the low-income area is a place where the median family income is less than 80% of the median family income of the surrounding vicinity.

questions.label: What was your company’s net job growth rate for full-time and part-time positions over the last 12 months? ONLY include newly created jobs that are paid a living wage.
questions.guidance: If there is no living wage data available for your country of operations, include new jobs that pay 10% or more above a minimum wage.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of current full and part-time workers and a list of full and part-time workers from 12 months ago that includes the wages of any employees hired to fill a new position (i.e. not an individual hired to replace someone).

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include the following:

1) Employee name or other indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc) for all employees as of the present day and 12 months ago.
2) Title.
3) Employment status and, if part-time, how many hours worked per week.

For the employees who were hired for a new position in the past 12 months, please also provide:

1) Employee's hourly pay (If the living wage date used is broken down by month vs. by hour, please calculate your employee's monthly salary instead (i.e. match your employee wage information to the pay period of the living wage data)).
2) Address of employment.

United States: livingwage.mit.edu
Selected other countries: https://www.globallivingwage.org/

You may redact employee names on any document.

questions.label: What percentage of full-time and part-time salaried workers left the company during the last twelve months?
questions.guidance: Calculation should include voluntary and involuntary separation, but exclude workers dismissed with cause.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide two lists: 1) a list of all current salaried employees and 2) a list of all salaried employees who worked for the company 12 months ago, noting the type of dismissal for employees who are no longer with the company.

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (i.e. Employee 1, Employee 2, etc). 
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time, part-time).
3) Wage type (i.e. salaried).
4) Type of dismissal, if applicable (i.e. voluntary separation, involuntary separation (without cause), dismissed with cause, etc).

Reminders
Termination with cause requires provable misconduct or documented performance problems with the employee.

questions.label: What percentage of temporary and seasonal workers of the last twelve months was previously employed with the company during prior growing seasons?
questions.guidance: Estimates within +/- 5% are acceptable. Please select N/A if you do not have temporary or seasonal workers.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of all temporary and seasonal workers hired in the last 12 months and indicate which have been employed by your company during previous growing seasons.

Reminders
You may redact employee names on any document (i.e. replace name with “Seasonal Employee 1,” “Temporary Employee 2” etc).

questions.label: What was your company’s net job growth rate for full-time and part-time positions over the last 12 months? ONLY include newly created jobs that are paid a living wage.
questions.guidance: If there is no living wage data available for your country of operations, include new jobs that pay 10% or more above a minimum wage.
