questions.label: How many of your company Board Directors identify as from another underrepresented social group?
questions.guidance: If collecting this type of demographic data is not legal in your jurisdiction, select N/A.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how many members of your company’s Board of Directors identify as an individual from an underrepresented group.

More Details
List of Board Members should include the following:

1) Role on the Board.
2) Individual’s Underrepresented Group Identity.
3) Total Number of Board Members.

Reminders
Underrepresented social groups generally include people from marginalized, low-income, or historically excluded populations. Please do not include gender, as it is captured in another question.

questions.label: How many of your company managers identify as from another underrepresented social group?
questions.guidance: If collecting this type of demographic data is not legal in your jurisdiction, select Don't Know.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the number of underrepresented individuals who hold managerial roles at your company as compared to overall management positions.

More Details
Sample documents include a list of managers or modified employee roster with the following information:

1) Manager’s Title.
2) Individual’s Underrepresented Group Identity.
3) Total Number of Managers at the Company.

Reminders
Underrepresented social groups generally include people from marginalized, low-income, or historically excluded populations. Please do not include gender, as it is captured in another question. 

You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: What percentage of full-time and part-time salaried workers left the company during the last twelve months?
questions.guidance: Calculation should include voluntary and involuntary separation, but exclude workers dismissed with cause.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide two lists: 1) a list of all current salaried employees and 2) a list of all salaried employees who worked for the company 12 months ago, noting the type of dismissal for employees who are no longer with the company.

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (i.e. Employee 1, Employee 2, etc). 
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time, part-time).
3) Wage type (i.e. salaried).
4) Type of dismissal, if applicable (i.e. voluntary separation, involuntary separation (without cause), dismissed with cause, etc).

Reminders
Termination with cause requires provable misconduct or documented performance problems with the employee.

questions.label: What percentage of full-time and part-time hourly workers left the company during the last twelve months?
questions.guidance: Calculation should include voluntary and involuntary separation, but exclude workers dismissed with cause.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide two lists: 1) a list of all current hourly employees and 2) a list of all hourly employees who worked for the company 12 months ago, noting the type of dismissal for employees who are no longer with the company.

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include:

1) Employee name or other indicator (i.e. Employee 1, Employee 2, etc). 
2) Employment status (i.e. full-time, part-time).
3) Wage type (i.e. hourly).
4) Type of dismissal, if applicable (i.e. voluntary separation, involuntary separation (without cause), dismissed with cause, etc).

Reminders
Termination with cause requires provable misconduct or documented performance problems with the employee.

questions.label: What was your company’s net job growth rate for full-time and part-time positions over the last 12 months? ONLY include newly created jobs that are paid a living wage.
questions.guidance: If there is no living wage data available for your country of operations, include new jobs that pay 10% or more above a minimum wage.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of current full and part-time workers and a list of full and part-time workers from 12 months ago that includes the wages of any employees hired to fill a new position (i.e. not an individual hired to replace someone).

More Details
Information can be provided in an edited employee roster or in a spreadsheet. Either should include the following:

1) Employee name or other indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc) for all employees as of the present day and 12 months ago.
2) Title.
3) Employment status and, if part-time, how many hours worked per week.

For the employees who were hired for a new position in the past 12 months, please also provide:

1) Employee's hourly pay (If the living wage date used is broken down by month vs. by hour, please calculate your employee's monthly salary instead (i.e. match your employee wage information to the pay period of the living wage data)).
2) Address of employment.
3) Living wage data for your area, including a link to the referenced source.

Reminders
The living wage is not the minimum wage. A living wage goes beyond meeting the minimum wage required by law and ensures that employees have the money necessary to meet living expenses in your region. It is a market-based approach that draws upon geographically specific expenditure data related to an individual’s likely minimum food, health insurance, housing, transportation, and other basic necessities (e.g. clothing, personal care items, etc.) costs.

Accepted living wage data can be found at the links below:

Canada: http://livingwagecanada.ca/
United Kingdom: livingwage.org.uk/calculation
United States: livingwage.mit.edu
Selected other countries: https://www.globallivingwage.org/

You may redact employee names on any document.

questions.label: How many of your non-managerial workers identify as women?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the number of female employees at your company as compared to the total workforce.

More Details
Sample documents include a list of female workers or modified employee roster with the following information:

1) Employee Name or Indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc.).
2) Gender of Employee.
3) Total Number of Employees at the Company.

Reminders
You may redact employee names on any document provided. 

Make sure to include both full-time and part-time workers.

questions.label: How many of your company Board Directors identify as women?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how many members of your company’s Board of Directors are women.

More Details
List of Board Members should include the following:

1) Role on the Board.
2) Gender.
3) Total Number of Board Members.

questions.label: What percentage of your purchases were from companies that are majority-owned by women or individuals from underrepresented populations?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of your suppliers from the last fiscal year who are majority owned by women or other underrepresented populations and the amount spent with each.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) The name of the supplier.
2) The total cost of goods/services purchased from that supplier during the last fiscal year.
3) A description of how the supplier meets the criteria of the question (e.g. owned by a woman, ethnic minority, a member of the LGBTQ community, an individual with a disability, etc).
4) The total amount spent with all suppliers last fiscal year.

Reminders
A supplier is any business that your company pays to provide a good or service. However, in the B Impact Assessment, suppliers will always exclude 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Other questions in the assessment speak to these providers.

questions.label: Does your company have any of the following policies or programs in place to promote diversity within your supply chain?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to demonstrate your company's intentional efforts to diversify your supply chain.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Supplier list that includes the demographic ownership of each. 
Checkbox 2: Supplier policy stating your company's preference for suppliers owned by individuals from underrepresented populations. 
Checkbox 3: Strategic plan that includes a quantitative goal to increase the diversity of the supply chain through purchasing.
Checkbox 4: Policy that includes a preference to utilize and support diverse suppliers and the program materials provided to those suppliers (e.g. presentation slides, videos, links to online trainings, reading materials, etc).

Reminders
Diverse or underserved groups include low income, poor, or very poor individuals, as well as demographic populations that have not traditionally had equal access to positive social or economic opportunities because of discrimination or other barriers. This may vary by context and geography. Gender, ethnicity, sexual-orientation, age, disabilities, immigration background, etc. may be considered. Please be prepared to provide data to validate your claim that a group is underserved, if requested.

questions.label: What percentage of the company is owned by individuals who would qualify as non-accredited investors?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a breakdown of company ownership and show which individuals meet the definition of a non-accredited investor.

More Details 
Modified capitalization table or spreadsheet should include:

1) List of all company owners.
2) Whether an owner is a non-accredited investor (see B Lab’s definition).
3) Number of shares owned by each non-accredited investor. 
4) Total company shares.

Reminders
Non-accredited investors are individuals with a net worth of less than $1.0 million USD and a household income of less than $200K for individuals and $300K if filing jointly. 

Owner names may be redacted.

questions.label: What percentage of the company is owned by individuals who would qualify as non-accredited investors?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a breakdown of company ownership and show which individuals meet the definition of a non-accredited investor.

More Details 
Modified capitalization table or spreadsheet should include:

1) List of all company owners.
2) Whether an owner is a non-accredited investor (see B Lab’s definition).
3) Number of shares owned by each non-accredited investor. 
4) Total company shares.

Reminders
Non-accredited investors are individuals with a net worth of less than $1.0 million USD and a household income of less than $200K for individuals and $300K if filing jointly. 

Owner names may be redacted.

questions.summary: Financing For Small Scale Farmers and Coop Members
questions.label: Does your company provide or enable any of the following short-term financing or letters of credit to the small-scale farmers or cooperative members that you source from?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if you are a farm that does not source from other farms.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation that illustrates the short-term financing or credit options your company makes available to the small-scale farmers or cooperative members in your supply chain.

More Details
Documents may include information given to suppliers about financing programs, executed short-term financing/letters of credit issued, template of the form that supplier must fill out to receive assistance, etc. Any document provided must include the lending rate offered by your company. Please also include the current commercial lending rate.

questions.label: Is your company majority-owned or -led by individuals from any of the following underrepresented groups?
questions.guidance: Please select all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of individuals with a diverse background who hold a majority-ownership stake in the company or are responsible for its leadership (i.e. President, CEO, etc). 

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Employee and/or Owner name or indicator (Employee 1, Employee 2, etc) 
2) Individual’s Underrepresented Group Identity.
3) Title, if an employee.
4) Percentage of overall shares owned, if a majority-owner.

Reminders
Diverse or underserved groups include low income, poor, or very poor individuals, as well as demographic populations that have not traditionally had equal access to positive social or economic opportunities because of discrimination or other barriers. This may vary by context and geography. Gender, ethnicity, sexual-orientation, age, disabilities, immigration background, etc. may be considered. Please be prepared to provide data to validate your claim that a group is underserved, if requested.

questions.label: What percentage of materials or products purchased have third-party social or environmental certification or approval or are from Significant Suppliers that are purpose-driven or have third-party company level certification or approval?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) a list of purchases from the last fiscal year in which either the supplier or the material/product has a third-party social or environmental certification and 2) the total amount spent on all significant suppliers.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Material/product purchased from that supplier.
3) Supplier's social or environmental certification (if applicable).
4) Material/product's social or environmental certification (if applicable).
5) Amount spent on each material/product purchased from a referenced supplier last fiscal year.
6) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers last fiscal year.  

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.label: What does your company formally screen for regarding the social or environmental practices and performance of your suppliers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the consistent and structured requirements that your company uses to evaluate a supplier’s social and environmental performance. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Documentation may include a purchasing/supplier screen policy or supplier evaluation reports that show what criteria suppliers are asked to meet.

Reminders
Reviewing supplier performance intermittently does not count for this question. There must be a formal, programmatic component to ensure that the desired behavior is regularly practiced throughout the company.

questions.label: What is the average tenure of your company's relationships with suppliers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a spreadsheet that demonstrates how long your company has done business with each of its significant suppliers. 

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) List of significant suppliers.
2) Length of relationship with each (in months). 
3) Amount spent with the supplier in the last fiscal year.
4) Total spent with all suppliers in the last fisal year.

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.label: How many of your company executives identify as from another underrepresented social group?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the number of underrepresented individuals who hold executive roles at your company as compared to overall executive positions.

More Details
Sample documents include a list of executives or modified employee roster with the following information:

1) Executive's Title.
2) Individual’s Underrepresented Group Identity.
3) Total Number of Executives at the Company.

Reminders
Underrepresented social groups generally include people from marginalized, low-income, or historically excluded populations. Please do not include gender, as it is captured in another question. 

You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: How many of your company managers identify as women?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the number of women who hold managerial roles at your company as compared to overall management positions.

More Details
Sample documents include a list of managers or modified employee roster with the following information:

1) Manager’s Title.
2) Gender of Manager.
3) Total Number of Managers at the Company.

Reminders
You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: Is there a formal written Supplier Code of Conduct policy that specifically holds your company's suppliers accountable for social and environmental performance?
questions.guidance: Your answers determine which future questions in the assessment are applicable to your company.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a Supplier Code of Conduct that states your company's social and environmental performance criteria. 

Reminders
Simply being mindful of your supplier's social and environmental impacts does not count for this question. There must be a written component. Codifying a company’s expectations in writing helps to ensure that your values are consistently practiced within the company and through your supply chain.

questions.label: What percentage of Significant Suppliers (on currency basis) are made transparent on your company's website?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of significant suppliers, the amount spent with each last fiscal year, and a link to where your relationship with the supplier can be found on your company's website.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Amount spent with each supplier in the last fiscal year.
3) Link to a page on your company’s website that includes the supplier. 
4) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers in the last fiscal year. 

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.label: How many of your company executives identify as women?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the number of women who hold executive roles at your company as compared to overall executive positions.

More Details
Sample documents include a list of executives or modified employee roster with the following information:

1) Executive's Title.
2) Gender of Executive Employee.
3) Total Number of Executive Employees at the Company.

Reminders
An executive is someone who is employed by a business at the highest level. Executives decide what the business should do, and ensure that it is done. Their scope of work usually extends beyond the management of individual person or project.

You may redact employee names on any document provided.

questions.label: During the last fiscal year, what percentage of products or crops grown (on currency basis) had an environmental certification?
questions.guidance: Certified crops may include fair trade, Rainforest Alliance, Starbucks C.A.F.E., Utz certification, International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movement certified, USDA Organic, Quality Assurance International - Certified Organic, EU Organic
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of products with an environmental certification that were sold last fiscal year, how much revenue was generated by each, and the company's total revenue from last fiscal year.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Product/crop description.
2) Environmental Certification held (e.g. USDA Organic, Rainforest Alliance, etc.).
3) Revenue generated by each last fiscal year.
4) Total revenue from last fiscal year.

If available, please also upload evidence of the certification (e.g. email confirmation from third-party auditor, certificate, link to webpage, etc).

questions.label: How do you collect a majority of the product from the farms or cooperative members you source from?
questions.guidance: Select only one.  Select N/A only if your company does not purchase product from other growers or has no crop purchase this year.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how purchased products get from a farm to your company’s location. 

More Details
Documents may include contracts with farmers/cooperative members, emails that arrange pick up or drop off, and/or company policies. 

Reminders
Answers must reflect the practices in place for the majority of products purchased from farmers.

questions.label: What is the average length of contract your company has with the farms you source from?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if your company does not purchase product from other growers or has no crop purchase this year.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) contracts with two different farmers and 2) a list of all supplier farms that includes the length of their contract. 

More Details
List or spreadsheet should include:

1) Farm Name.
2) Whether your company has a contract with each Farm.
3) Length of contract terms (in months), if applicable. 

Reminders
Please state the duration of the original contract, not how much time is left on the contract.

questions.label: What are your company's policies regarding independent contractors that do not work for the company greater than 20 hours per week for longer than a 6 month period?
questions.guidance: Independent contractors that work for the company 20+ hours per week over a 6+ month period should be considered in the Workers section.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company seeks to support the growth and well-being of independent contractors who work for the company for fewer than 20 hours per week for a period of less than 6 months.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Evaluation form that your company fills out and shares with independent contractors at the end of a project. 
Checkbox 2: Feedback form that contractors are given at the end of a project to share their thoughts on working with your company.
Checkbox 3: Contract that states the expected length of time for the project or includes an offer of employment, communications between the company and the contractor that make it clear that the contractor is working for multiple clients.
Checkbox 4: List of current independent contractors (using name or other identifier, i.e. Independent Contractor 1, 2, etc) that includes their hourly rate, the individual’s location (city and state), and the living wage for that area. Please also provide a link to the living wage data used to determine your answer. 

Reminders
If available, please provide copies of a completed evaluation or feedback form, not a template. Contractor names or other sensitive information can be redacted. 

The living wage is not the minimum wage. A living wage goes beyond meeting the minimum wage required by law and ensures that employees have the money necessary to meet living expenses in your region. It is a market-based approach that draws upon geographically specific expenditure data related to an individual’s likely minimum food, health insurance, housing, transportation, and other basic necessities (e.g. clothing, personal care items, etc.) costs.

Accepted living wage data can be found at the links below:

Canada: http://livingwagecanada.ca/
United Kingdom: livingwage.org.uk/calculation
United States: livingwage.mit.edu
Selected other countries: https://www.globallivingwage.org/

questions.label: What % of Significant Suppliers (on currency basis) are  subjected to regular quality assurance reviews or audits?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of significant suppliers who have completed quality assurance evaluations and the amount spent with each supplier last fiscal year. In addition, please upload the results of a supplier quality assurance review or audit.

More Details
List or spreadsheet should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Description of quality assurance activity that states who completed the review/audit, the scope of work, and how frequently it occurs.
3) Amount spent with each supplier in the last fiscal year.
4) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers in the last fiscal year. 

Documentation to illustrate the results of the supplier's quality assurance assessments can include a completed audit or a screengrab of a summary page in your data collection platform.

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.summary: Advance Purchase Provisions for  Farmers and Cooperatives
questions.label: If you enter into advance purchase agreements, do you provide the following to the small-scale farmers or cooperative members that you source from?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if you are a farm that does not source from other farms.
questions.documentationText: Please provide copies of any contracts or communication materials detailing the advance pricing arrangements and related policies and practices of your company.

questions.label: If you purchase product from farms or cooperative members, does your company utilize any of the following product collection mechanisms?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if your company does not purchase product from other growers or has no crop purchase this year.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide at least two example purchase agreements that clearly state that growers are expected to be present during product quality checks and/or that a different price will be provided for varying levels of quality. The presence of growers can also be verified by uploading photographs that illustrate the weighing and quality check process, including detailed captions and an indication of which individuals in the pictures are the farmers.

Reminders
These practices must be in place for all farms and/or cooperative members.

questions.label: What methods does your company use to evaluate the social or environmental impact of your suppliers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company monitors the social or environmental performance of your suppliers. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Email or welcome packet sent to suppliers that includes policies/rules around social or environmental performance.
Checkbox 2: Sample social or environmental impact assessment designed by company for suppliers. 
Checkbox 3: Email or welcome packet sent to suppliers with instructions to complete a third-party risk or impact assessment.
Checkbox 4: Two most recent dated audits/reviews of the social or environmental performance of your suppliers.
Checkbox 5: Contract with a third-party to complete an assessment of the social or environmental performance of your suppliers at least every two years.
Checkbox 6: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding your company evaluation of the social or environmental impact of your suppliers.

questions.label: During the last fiscal year, what percentage of your Significant Suppliers (on currency basis) had internationally-recognized product certifications?
questions.guidance: Select 0% if you do not know whether your Significant Suppliers are certified.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of significant suppliers from the last fiscal year whose products have an internationally-recognized product certification and the total amount spent on all significant suppliers.

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) List of product certifications held by supplier.
3) Amount spent on each supplier last fiscal year.
4) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers last fiscal year.  

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.summary: Sourcing From Small-Scale Farmers or Coop Members
questions.label: Do you source from small-scale farmers, or is your company a cooperative?
questions.guidance: Your answers determine which future questions in the assessment are applicable to your company.

questions.label: What is the average tenure of your company's relationships with suppliers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a spreadsheet that demonstrates how long your company has done business with each of its significant suppliers. 

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) List of significant suppliers.
2) Length of relationship with each (in months). 
3) Amount spent with the supplier in the last fiscal year.
4) Total spent with all suppliers in the last fisal year.

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.label: What areas of social and environmental performance are specifically included in your company's Supplier Code of Conduct policy?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a Supplier Code of Conduct that states your company's social and environmental performance criteria and auditing mechanisms, if applicable. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

Reminders
Simply being mindful of your supplier's social and environmental impacts does not count for this question. There must be a written component. Codifying a company’s expectations in writing helps to ensure that your values are consistently practiced within the company and through your supply chain.

questions.label: Please select the types of companies that represent your Significant Suppliers:
questions.guidance: All companies have significant suppliers, which are defined as the largest suppliers of the company amounting to approximately 80% of non-labor costs.  Select all that apply.

questions.label: Does your company do any of the following to support small scale or other in-need suppliers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation of your company's actions to aid the success of small scale and in-need suppliers. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Report or presentation summarizing your completed supplier needs assessment.
Checkbox 2: Description of supplier education or support program from the company’s governing documents or website. 
Checkbox 3: Contracts between the company and at least two small scale/in-need suppliers and a contract from a large-scale supplier that demonstrate the same terms.
Checkbox 4: Contracts or invoices/receipts for at least two small scale/in-need suppliers that demonstrate 30 days payables outstanding. 
Checkbox 5: Supplier satisfaction surveys or links to satisfaction surveys that are consistently shared with small-scale/in-need suppliers. 
Checkbox 6: Contract or welcome packet for a new small scale/in-need supplier that includes a description of a consistent grievance and resolution process.
Checkbox 7: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding your support of small scale or other in-need suppliers.

questions.label: Over the last twelve months, did your company have a formal education and support program for the contract farmers or cooperative members that you source from?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if you are a farm that does not source from other farms.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide evidence to illustrate the experience of a contract farmer or cooperative member participating in your company's supplier training program over the last 12 months.

More Details
Documents may include dated training materials, supplier contracts that describe education or support programs, or receipts from the purchases of improved technology. Please also include documentation that explains which suppliers are eligible for these benefits.

questions.label: Have you assisted the small-scale farmers or cooperative members that you source from in getting fair-trade, organic, or other internationally-recognized product certification?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if you are a farm that does not source from other farms.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide evidence of the actions taken by your company to help your small-scale farmers or cooperative suppliers earn an internationally-recognized certification. 

More Details
Documentation may include training materials, communications with suppliers, educational resources, receipts of financial support leading to certification, etc. Please also provide copies of any certifications obtained.

questions.label: Does your company control any land under cultivation?
questions.guidance: This question will help to pre-fill the N/A option for questions not applicable to your business.

questions.label: Is your company a cooperative or does it source produce from other growers?
questions.guidance: This question will help to pre-fill the N/A option for questions not applicable to your business.

questions.summary: Third Party Traceability and Labeling Standards
questions.label: Do you comply with third-party traceability and labeling standards to ensure that the origination and supply chain of all products is tracked?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a copy of the third-party standard or certification used by your company to create product traceability from origination through the entire supply chain (e.g. HAACP).

Reminders
These principles must be in place for all products.

questions.label: What kind of facilities does your business primarily operate in?
questions.guidance: Your answers determine which future questions in the assessment are applicable to your company.

questions.label: In the last 12 months, what % of Significant Suppliers (on currency basis) are subjected to regular audits by independent third party auditors against recognized food safety principles?
questions.guidance: Select N/A only if you are a farm that does not source from other farms.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a list of significant suppliers who have completed independent food safety inspections in the past 12 months and the amount spent with each supplier last fiscal year. In addition, please upload the results of at least one of those audits.

More Details
List or spreadsheet should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Description of food safety audit that states who completed the audit, the standard used, and how often the audits occur.
3) Amount spent with each supplier in the last fiscal year.
4) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers in the last fiscal year. 

Documentation to illustrate the results of the supplier's food safety audits can include a completed audit or a screengrab of a summary page in your data collection platform.

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.summary: Sourcing % of COGS from Local Suppliers
questions.label: Sourcing of COGS Local to Customers
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate the amount spent with independent suppliers who are within 200 miles of your customers. 

More Details
Two sets of data are required: 1) supplier information and 2) customer information.

Supplier spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Supplier’s address (city, state, country). 
3) Amount spent with that supplier during the last fiscal year.
4) Total amount spent with all suppliers last fiscal year. 

Customer spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) List of company products.
2) Revenue received from each product.
3) What percentage of that product (by revenue) was delivered or purchased by someone local to your company (i.e. calculated based on addresses on customer invoices). 
4) Total revenue from all products. 

If your company is a service provider, please provide a customer spreadsheet but, instead of listing company products, break down your revenues by client and include the client’s address.

Reminders
Supplier data does not need to be provided for all suppliers, only those that are within 200 miles of your customers. If your customers are not all concentrated in a specific area, consider focusing only on the location/s of the greatest number of customers and any nearby suppliers. 

A supplier is any business that your company pays to provide a good or service. However, in the B Impact Assessment, suppliers will always exclude 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Other questions in the assessment speak to these providers.

questions.label: During the last fiscal year, what percentage of products or crops grown (on currency basis) had an environmental certification?
questions.guidance: Certified crops may include fair trade, Rainforest Alliance, Starbucks C.A.F.E., Utz certification, International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movement certified, USDA Organic, Quality Assurance International - Certified Organic, EU Organic
questions.documentationText: Please provide evidence of the % of Significant Suppliers that have third-party company-level certifications or approvals. List Significant Suppliers with certifications, amount spent with each, and name of certification. Also provide the total amount spent with Significant Suppliers in the last FY. You may use the provided template or modify an existing list.

questions.summary: Sourcing % raw materials from Local Suppliers
questions.label: Raw materials (in currency terms) grown or harvested
questions.guidance: By company or local independent suppliers.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how much of your purchased raw materials were grown or harvested within 200 miles/322 km of your customers last fiscal year. 

More Details
Two sets of data are required, one about the raw materials and the other about where the end product was used. Please include the following information in a spreadsheet (or similar).

For the Raw Materials:
1) Description of raw material.
2) City + state + country in which the raw material was grown/harvested.
3) Amount spent on each raw material last fiscal year.
4) Total amount spent on all raw materials last fiscal year.

For the End Products:
If your company has physical storefronts, please list their addresses (city + state + country), how much revenue was generated by each location, and total revenues from all products sold last fiscal year.

If your company sells and ships products, please list the revenue generated by customer location (city + state + country) and total revenue from last fiscal year.

Reminders
End product information does not have to be comprehensive. It should only reflect those locations that are within 200 miles/322 km of your suppliers. For example, the fictional company, “All Things Apple,” sells apples and apple tree seeds. Both products come from a supplier farm in the same town as the company; however, the apples are sold at the town Farmer’s Market, while the apple tree seeds are shipped worldwide. As such, the company might choose only to provide the requested details on the apple farmer and the revenue generated at the Farmer’s Market, instead of itemizing all global purchases.

questions.summary: Social or Environmental Screening of Suppliers
questions.label: Does your company screen or evaluate Significant Suppliers for social and environmental impact?
questions.guidance: This question determines the set of supplier-focused questions your company will respond to.

questions.label: Has your company implemented an environmentally-efficient shipping or distribution policy?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a shipping or distribution policy that includes instructions for minimizing the company’s transportation-related environmental footprint.

Reminders
Simply engaging in the behaviors mentioned above does not count for this question. There must be a written component. Codifying a company’s expectations in writing helps to ensure that your values are consistently practiced within the company.

questions.label: What is the average tenure of your company's relationships with suppliers?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide a spreadsheet that demonstrates how long your company has done business with each of its significant suppliers. 

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) List of significant suppliers.
2) Length of relationship with each (in months). 
3) Amount spent with the supplier in the last fiscal year.
4) Total spent with all suppliers in the last fisal year.

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.label: Has your company adopted any of the following techniques for minimizing the transportation-related environmental impact of its distribution and supply chain?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company seeks reduce the negative environmental impact of transportation in its distribution and supply chain. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected. 

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: List of company and/or supplier clean or low-emission vehicles, policy to purchase/use clean or low-emission vehicles to transport products.
Checkbox 2: Screenshot of a strategic planning software interface that minimizes fuel usage and the company’s shipping footprint, receipt for the purchase of relevant software.
Checkbox 3: Training materials (e.g. slide decks, videos, handouts, etc) or receipts of purchased training on fuel efficient driving.
Checkbox 4: Policy to use freight or shipping methods with a reduced environmental impact. 
Checkbox 5: Please provide evidence of the claim made regarding the use of techniques to minimize the transportation-related environmental impact of your distribution and supply chain.

questions.label: If you are a cooperative or source product from other farms: Do a majority of members/supplier farms comply with sustainable land-use policies?
questions.guidance: Select N/A if your company is not a cooperative or does not purchase product from other growers.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) documentation to illustrate expectations around sustainable land-use for the majority of your supplier farms and 2) a list of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Documents may include supplier contracts that specify sustainable land-use practices or a required certification for the sustainable management of agricultural ecosystems. Supplier surveys confirming adherence to sustainable land-use policies may also be uploaded.

Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Farm name.
2) Sustainable land use principles employed.
3) Certifications held, if applicable.
4) Amount spent with each farm last fiscal year.
5) Total spent with all supplier farmers last fiscal year.
6) Total number of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year.

questions.label: If you are a cooperative or source product from other farms: Do a majority of members/supplier farms follow these soil-management policies?
questions.guidance: Select N/A if your company is not a cooperative or does not purchase product from other growers.
questions.documentationText:
Overview

More Details
Documents may include supplier contracts that specify the selected soil management activities. Supplier surveys confirming adherence to soil management policies may also be uploaded.

Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Farm name.
2) Relevant soil management practices employed.
3) Amount spent with each farm last fiscal year.
4) Total spent with all supplier farmers last fiscal year.
5) Total number of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year.

questions.label: Do a majority of members/supplier farms monitor any of the following biodiversity issues for land-under-cultivation?
questions.documentationText:

5) Total number of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year.

questions.label: What percentage of materials or products purchased have third-party social or environmental certification or approval or are from Significant Suppliers that are purpose-driven or have third-party company level certification or approval?
questions.documentationText:
Overview

More Details
Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Supplier name.
2) Material/product purchased from that supplier.
3) Supplier's social or environmental certification (if applicable).
4) Material/product's social or environmental certification (if applicable).
5) Amount spent on each material/product purchased from a referenced supplier last fiscal year.
6) Total amount spent with all significant suppliers last fiscal year.  

Reminders
Significant suppliers are providers of goods or services (including independent contractors) that would be included in a list of your top 80% of purchases. Please exclude from your supplier list 1) your landlord, 2) your utility company, and 3) the entity to which you pay your taxes. Asking about your significant suppliers allows us to focus on the choices made regarding your most consistent and material expenses.

questions.label: Do a majority of members/supplier farms have safeguards in place to ensure that no prohibited pesticides are applied to land under-cultivation (see Help Text)?
questions.guidance: Please answer if you are a cooperative or source product from other farms.  Select N/A if your company is not a cooperative or does not purchase product from other growers.
questions.documentationText:

3) Amount spent with each farm last fiscal year.

questions.label: Do a majority of cooperative members/supplier farms monitor and record energy usage for cultivation and distribution of products sold? (Majority by cost basis, land under cultivation or headcount)
questions.guidance: Please answer if you are a cooperative or source product from other farms.  Select N/A if your company is not a cooperative or does not purchase product from other growers.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) documentation to illustrate the type and scope of energy monitoring and recording at the majority of your supplier farms and 2) a list of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Documents may include supplier contracts that specify expected practices around monitoring and recording energy use, a required third-party certification (please also upload the relevant criteria for the certification) or supplier surveys.

Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

2) Type and scope of energy monitoring and recording practice. 
3) Amount spent with each farm last fiscal year.
4) Total spent with all supplier farmers last fiscal year.
5) Total number of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year.

If calculating "majority" by land-under-cultivation, please also include the amount of land-under-cultivation of each supplier and the land-under-cultivation from all supplier farms last fiscal year.

questions.label: Which of the following types of pesticides do a majority of members/supplier farms apply to land-under-cultivation?
questions.guidance: Please answer if you are a cooperative or source product from other farms.  Select N/A if your company is not a cooperative or does not purchase product from other growers.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide 1) documentation to illustrate the type of pesticides applied by the majority of your supplier farms and 2) a list of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

3) Amount spent with each farm last fiscal year.
4) Total spent with all supplier farmers last fiscal year.
5) Total number of farms sourced from in the last fiscal year.

Reminders
Pesticide classifications can be found in the WHO’s “Recommended Classification of Pesticides by Hazard” at the following link: https://www.who.int/ipcs/publications/pesticides_hazard/en/

questions.label: Does the company currently use any of the following specific practices to reduce carbon emissions from transportation?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company reduces the carbon footprint of the transportation needs of its employees and/or products. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Employee handbook that includes details of transit subsidies, receipts for purchase of transit subsidies for workers.
Checkbox 2-3: Shipping policies.
Checkbox 4: Please provide evidence for the claim made regarding the use of specific practices to reduce carbon emissions from transportation.

questions.summary: Tracking Chemicals in the Supply Chain
questions.label: Does your company do any of the following to manage chemicals in the supply chain?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how the company monitors chemicals that may be present in its supply chain. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 1: Supplier Code of Conduct or supplier survey that includes a requirement to disclose specific chemicals that are of concern to your company.
Checkbox 2: Supplier survey, supplier checklist, etc. that asks suppliers about their chemical tracking and management activities.
Checkbox 3: Supplier Code of Conduct or supplier contract that requires suppliers provide their chemical information to a third party.
Checkbox 4: Examples of general correspondence shared with suppliers in different markets that include a Restricted Substances List and expectations your company has for compliance (i.e. fill out a supplier survey, etc).
Checkbox 5: Supplier contract or welcome packet that details incentives for participation in the company’s chemical management program.

Reminders
Practices must be reflective of consistent actions taken regarding the majority of product materials, not occasional inquiries.  

Chemicals in this context may include:

CMRs: carcinogens, mutagens, and reproductive toxins
PBTs: persistent, bioaccumulative, and toxic chemicals
EDRs: endocrine disruptors or hormone-disrupting chemicals

questions.label: Does the company currently use any of the following specific practices to reduce carbon emissions from transportation?
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how your company reduces the carbon footprint of its product transportation. 

More Details
Sample documents include shipping policies or other consistant and comprehensive instructions given to employees on expectations regarding frieght shipment (e.g. training materials).

questions.label: Have you reduced the ton miles (relative to revenues) of your distribution and supply chain, and if so, by how much?
questions.guidance: Calculate by comparing ton-miles from the year prior or annualized from a baseline year.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please demonstrate to what degree the company has minimized the environmental impact from shipping and freight transportation by reducing its ton miles relative to revenues over time.

More Details
One set of documents to illustrate this answer could be:

a) Shipping report which includes the ton miles of your distribution and supply chain last fiscal year + revenue last fiscal year.
b) Shipping report which includes the ton miles of your distribution and supply chain from the fiscal year prior to the last fiscal year + revenue from the fiscal year prior to the last fiscal year.

If your company monitors this information using a different timeframe, please provide the details in that format. However, the evidence must reflect a significant comparable time period and include both the ton miles and revenue.

questions.summary: Tracking Chemicals in the Supply Chain
questions.label: Does your company do any of the following to track chemicals in the supply chain for the majority of materials?
questions.guidance: Please check all that apply.
questions.documentationText:
Overview
Please provide documentation to illustrate how the company monitors chemicals that may be present in its supply chain. Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Sample documents:

Checkbox 2: Supplier Code of Conduct or supplier survey that includes a requirement to disclose specific chemicals that are of concern to your company.
Checkbox 3: Supplier survey, supplier checklist, etc. that asks suppliers about their chemical tracking and management activities.
Checkbox 4: Supplier Code of Conduct or supplier contract that requires suppliers provide their chemical information to a third party.
Checkbox 5: Link to the page on your website that states all by-products, contaminants, or trace materials for a majority of your products.

Reminders
Practices must be reflective of consistent actions taken regarding the majority of product materials, not occasional inquiries.  

Chemicals in this context may include:

CMRs: carcinogens, mutagens, and reproductive toxins
PBTs: persistent, bioaccumulative, and toxic chemicals
EDRs: endocrine disruptors or hormone-disrupting chemicals

Evidence must be provided for each answer option selected.

More Details
Documents may include supplier contracts that specify expected sustainability certifications (please also include certification criteria) or require specific best management practices. Supplier surveys confirming adherence to sustainable land-use policies may also be uploaded.

Spreadsheet (or similar) should include:

1) Farm name.
2) Certifications held and/or sustainable land use principles employed.
3) Number of acres at each farm in which those principles were applied last fiscal year. 
4) Total acres of all land managed for production from supplier farms last fiscal year.
